Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 05:41AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Diane, I have a feeling your sinus problems are a SE. I'd never had a bloody nose in my life, until chemo. Now the sinus pressure and pain, running nose and bloody discharge happen after every infusion. Loved the "horrible wig" stories. I bought one inexpensive one online and when I put it on, I laughed out loud. It was long, curly, blonde and layered. I looked like a stripper or pole dancer! I bought several more from a local shop and the cosmetologist offered to trim it. It looks a lot better now, with bangs, the pieces around my face trimmed and overall length shortened. One day I was in the grocery store, bending over the bakery products, when the bakery employee said, "Oh, your hair is so shiny and beautiful." I told her I had breast cancer, and she started crying. We exchanged names, and now I have a new friend. And Saturday, I was in another store, when the woman waiting on me said, "Do you mind if I ask you a personal question?" I was sure she had spotted my wig and was going to ask about cancer. But no, what she said was, "Your hair is about the same length as mine. Can you tell me where you get it cut?" I lifted it up, and told her I was going through chemo. She was very sweet. So there are some uplifting wig stories out there. Just keep trying until you find one that works for you. (I still hate wearing it. It's hot and itchy, and it's the middle of winter. I don't know what I'll do this summer.)  Alison, good luck on your first treatment today. Whatever SE you experience, you'll find someone on this thread or another one who has had the very same SE and can help you through them.  Have a good week, everyone!
Posts.Title: January 2012 chemo ely Momof2inME

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 04:37AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Catwhispurr, I agree with Rachel that you should tell your MO about the neuropathy. I find that I am now obsessed with other women's beautiful hair. I was in a deli yesterday frequented by college students, and oh, their long, beautiful thick hair! I was so jealous. One of the worst things is knowing how long it will take to regrow to its previous shoulder length, and worrying whether it will be thinner or grayer. It will really piss me off to have to continue to wear a wig long after chemo is over.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 05:26AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Alajohn, yes, I've received Neulasta shots after each of my three T/C treatments. Generally the SE for me have been cherry-red cheeks and body aches, helped significantly by taking both Claritin and Tylenol.  Annie3310, about your scheduled book reading...I have found that the day after my treatments, I am fine. The steroids are still in my system, I have energy and the anti-nausea meds are keeping that awful SE at bay. After the first treatment, I had 4 good days before the "hit-by-a-bus" feeling hit me. After the second and third treatments, that feeling hit on Day #3. You might want to have a back-up plan, just in case, like reading while sitting instead of standing. But I have a feeling you'll be OK and can enjoy and celebrate that wonderful accomplishment. FLDreamer, I've read on some other posts of women who have had severe ringing in their ears after treatment. What I've experienced is the sound of blood pumping in my ears, a whoosh-whoosh that is annoying. Others have mentioned their hearing being more sensitive, too. May today be better than yesterday, tomorrow be better than today...every day gets us one day closer to being finished with treatment!

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 03:36AM WaveWhisperer wrote: NancyHB, hot flashes are a pretty common side effect, and I've had some doozies while on chemo. These hot flashes are far worse than those I experienced when I went through menopause. Part of the reason mine might be so bad is that I had been on hormone replacement therapy after menopause and I had to stop those cold-turkey the day I got my diagnosis of BC. The night sweats have been especially annoying. I've gotten so I lay out a fresh set of pj's every night, with a towel, so if I wake up soaked, I can walk into the bathroom, wipe off with the towel, put on fresh pj's and get back into bed without turning on a light, almost without even opening my eyes. A nurse told me that some foods and drinks exacerbate the hot flashes, including red wine and chocolate, which had been two of my favorite vices. I've cut out both, and it does help some.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2012 01:48PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Help! I'm almost 8 months PFC and my once straight, shoulder-length blonde (well, triple-processed, with base, highlights and lowlights) hair has come in completely gray and curly. I look in the mirror and see my mother. I feel invisible. Nobody recognizes me. So I finally decided to color it. I was worried about peroxide or ammonia, so first I tried a dark blonde shade of the Roux Fanci-Full rinse-out color. Nothing. Not a hair changed. I went back and bought a Clairol professional Soy 4-Plex semi-permament color -- dark blonde/light brown -- mixed it and left it on the maximum 45 minutes (which it said for coverage of gray). Again, almost no effect whatsoever. Maybe some of my near-white hair is a muddier gray, but that's only on one side of my head, where the hair is the softest.  I think it's time to go back to a professional. Do you think it's safe? What will it take to turn my steel gray-to-almost-white head of 2-inch curls into a straight, shoulder-length head of blonde hair?? (A wig, I know!!!) I was just kidding about the last part, but what will it take to turn me blonde again, and is it safe?  (Plus I went so long without needing a hairdresser that when I finally went to the salon for a neck trim, my stylist was no longer there and they wouldn't tell me where he went. So now I have to look for someone new.) Had I had any idea how long and sad this hair process would be, I would have gone through the hassle of Cold Caps in a minute. I feel like I'm no longer a cancer "patient," but I feel like I look like one.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 09:31PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Eight months PFC, and I just had my first (and second) hair appointment for a trim and color. What an experience! My previously long, blonde, highlighted hair came in completely gray and curly. Even though I'm a grandmother, I couldn't stand looking my age! I felt invisible; I felt like I looked like my own mother. First, I tried at-home semi-permanent color. Nothing. I had an appointment with a new stylist Tuesday (my old one disappeared in the year when I had no need of one). I showed her pix of the "old me." She said she'd have to use a darker base than I was used to to fully cover the steel gray in back. It came out really dark, and I was almost in tears. She said she would add highlights but didn't have time that day, so we made an appointment for yesterday. I showed up, to find that she had gotten sick, so they rescheduled me for today. My hair was too short for foils, so she had to pull out that antique rubber cap. After all that, though, the highlights were barely visible. She said we'd try foil after all, even though it was difficult. Then it still was a little dark, so she combined some stuff with shampoo to lighten me a bit. Well, after 5 hours in the salon and three visits there, I can now say that I no longer have gray hair. Or dark brown hair. It's still not where I want it, but by the time I go again, it should be longer and easier to use foils.  I never imagined losing our hair and trying to get it back would be so hard!!

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 12:13PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Caitlin, when shopping for wigs, consider your local American Cancer Society office. Often they have wigs donated by former cancer patients, and you can get them free. Or check to see whether your hospital or cancer center has a shop on location offering products for cancer patients. I got a nice wig at my cancer center's shop, and a nearby stylist trimmed it to my liking for free. I also ordered reasonably priced wigs from the American Cancer Society's TLC catalog (also online) and several wigs from e-wigs.com. E-wigs will send you a ring of color samples for a small charge, then refund your money when you send the samples back. That's a good way to check color before ordering. For all my wigs, I've had a professional stylist trim them to suit me.  IMHO, the natural hair wigs are not worth the money. I bought one expensive human-hair wig, and it's my least favorite. It's not as shiny and I never found a way to really style it.  I also highly recommend the "Look Good, Feel Better" program offered by the ACS. You get oodles of nice cosmetics (high-end brands) and good suggestions on using the makeup.

I look like an old man.  I'm glad so many others had good luck with radiation, and little or no burning. I have very fair, sensitive skin and, despite using the RO-prescribed gel every day, I got a very severe radiation burn on the breast and chest. Posts.Content: May 27, 2012 08:35AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Rockym, I feel the same way. I am VERY thankful to be alive. I just wish I looked well.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2013 07:24AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Agree with Iago that "your hair will be more beautiful than ever" is BS. I'm 14 months PFC and my hairline is different (more of that male-pattern with thin areas over both eyes); I have cowlicks I never had before; the texture is much finer; the hair grew back curly (although it gradually is loosening from its poodle self); it's not as shiny; and, even after more than a year, the length barely covers my ears. I'm happy to have hair and enough hair now that it looks like someone meant to have it this way. I've colored and highlighted it 3 times, and that has made me feel a lot better. I tried those 28-day colors, but none would cover the gray. I finally went to a salon and my hair was so different that it took 3 tries to get an accceptable color. (I took a bag of my old hair with me. Very sad.) My hair was so short the stylist couldn't use foils and had to pull hair through that gross rubber cap. As for stress, I know from experience, and the scientific research backs up the fact that stress can lower your immune system and wreak havoc on your body. After an especially stressful six-month period of my life (death of ex-spouse, child graduating from high school and going to college, selling 2 homes (including ex-spouse's and all his belongings) and buying one with fiance, moving,marrying and getting a huge job promotion), I developed extreme panic attacks and, within 13 months, had two major surgeries, one for colon cancer, one for compressed spinal cord. Myleftboob, congrats on geting rid of that 230-pound stressor!!

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2011 10:24PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Hello, all. I'm joining the TC December train. Thanks to Leesa for creating it and for messaging me that it was here. I will have TCx4, starting on 12/20, so let me know if anyone else is on that schedule. I see ckk starts 12/22. Your comments make me nervous about SE, but they also are reassuring. When I encounter something, I'll know I'm not the first or only one, that there's usually something to counter-act it and that better days will come. With my first treatment on 12/20, I'm worried about how I'll feel on Christmas. I usually host a family dinner party on Christmas Eve, with turkey and all the fixings. You think this year maybe I should plan to order pre-cooked stuff from Whole Foods rather than trying to cook all that myself? Give me your best tips on what I should stock up on before Treatment 1, and what I should take beforehand. I know I need to drink lots of water before, during and after to flush out the chemicals. I've read that Claritin helps, but I'm not sure what that's for. What do you suggest I have on hand for constipation (I HATE that!) And someone suggested Prevacid. I ended up choosing chemo, even though my tumor was small, with clear margins, and my Oncotype score was 8. I did have micromets, which means my MO considers me node-positive, although I know some would not. She said I could forego chemo but she recommended it, so here I am, nervous as all get-out. I'm going to look at wigs today. I considered cold caps, but I'm not sure I can deal with all the logistics of that, especially since it's just my husband and me. Any tips on buying wigs? Anything else? I can't tell you how wonderful it is to have so many new friends online. Nobody -- and I mean nobody -- really knows what we're going through, no matter how much they love you and want to help. In the end, this is a one-on-one battle, us vs. cancer. Thanks again!

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 11:22PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Thanks to all of you for your good advice. I couldn't get through the day without that caffeine. I'm in the South, of course, so it's not all that unusual. But when I used to travel on business, especially in places like NYC, the waiters would be very confused when I ordered DietCoke for breakfast. I often took to carrying my own, in my purse. Thought it interesting that your MO expected a high Oncotype score with your grade 3 tumor. Leesa, hope your fevers are down soon! Hope everyone has a good day!! Wave

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 11:26PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Rachel, good to hear from you. Has your mom arrived yet? Your apartment in good shape? Anniebell, my steroids kicked in full-tilt after yesterday's #2 infusion. I tried a long soak in the tub last night, but that didn't help. I was wide awake until 2:30, cleaned the bathroom and bedroom, washed all the dishes, cleaned countertops, read and discarded mail, organized my meds, wrote some long e-mails. I would have run the washer and vacuum if my DH hadn't been asleep and needing to get up for an 8 am appointment. Even at 2:30, I took a sleeping pill and 2 Ativan. I'm not sure I was supposed to take all that. At first I feared I might have OD'd myself, but I was awake for good at 7. Today I go for my Neulasta shot. And I'll be taking my Claritin before I go. I had asked my MO about it before the first one, and she said she had heard from many patients that it helped, but she had no scientific proof of it. She said she and other researcher had thought about doing a clinical trial but never got around to it. Bottom line, she said: If it helps, do it. Good luck to Thursday's girls!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 10:23AM - edited Jan 24, 2012 10:25AM by WaveWhisperer Robin, definitely go for the sleeping pills. I haven't been able to sleep without help since my D/X. For a few lovely weeks, I was sleeping like a baby -- until I told the oncology nurse that I was taking 2 Ativan before bedtime. She said I couldn't keep doing that, that it could become addictive and that I shouldn't use it on top of the anti-depressant they were giving me. Now I'm on a sleeping pill, but I don't sleep as well as with the Ativan. Very, very vivid dreams! (Gracie, I was taking 10 mg of Ativan, so you've got a long way to go before you get to that level.) Bela, I agree with HeatherB that, no matter how awful our side effects, we are committed to doing everything possible to keep this disease at bay. Like you, I have had horrible diarrhea. Before my first treatment, I was prepared for the opposite reaction, constipation, and had loaded up on all sorts of laxatives. Imagine my surprise when diarrhea hit several times an hour.  I ended up with such dehydration that I had to go in for two bags of IVs. My doc then put me on Immodium and Nexium, so it's been much less severe. After suggesting that we add our treatment schedules to our signatures, I don't think I did it right myself. Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 12:46AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Gracie and Heatherb, thanks for the tip on adding my treatment dates. We'll see if it worked. Gracie, a big oops by me. When you were talking about taking 1 mg of Ativan, I replied that I was taking 10 mg. I looked at the bottle last night and each pill was .5 mg, not 5 mg, so I was taking 1 mg, not 10.   Rachel, we're proud of you for your participation in "Pirates of Penzance" despite your chemo. Have you told us what instrument you play?  Glad you had a good birthday with your parents. Ckk, yes, we've all been down there in that black hole with you. Mine is a little deeper and lasts a little longer every cycle. You feel so alone, while your friends and, seemingly, the rest of the world goes about their happy way. I got especially depressed when I looked at what used to be some of my favorite women's magazines. Articles about fashion, about how to organize your time, where to vacation, ads for hair color, razors and shaving cream, shampoos and conditioners, mascara, creams to minimize wrinkles, to take '10 years off." It seems like they're written in a foreign language now. I'm no longer one of those women. They don't get me. I can't remember whether your MO prescribed an anti-depressant for you or not. I'm on one, and I think it helps...at least some. I imagine I would be worse without it. Regardless, just keep in mind that we're all here to listen and that you just need to get through one day at a time and eventually this will be over. BTW, I, too, keep having twinges and aches in the OTHER breast. In fact, it was that breast that I asked my ob/gyn about when I went for my annual exam in September.  She couldn't feel anything unusual in either one. It was my regularly scheduled mammo 2 weeks later that discovered the tumor in my right one.  After my DX, the BS scheduled an MRI for me on BOTH breasts, and the left one showed up clear. I can't imagine that something has popped up there since then, and with chemo. But I'll ask about it. Like Heatherb, I'm really fatigued but the terrible mouth taste has backed off. I was still awake at 1:30 this morning, despite my sleeping pill. I finally took an Ativan. Treatment #3 a week from today. Ugh. This is so much tougher than I imagined. Naive me, I thought that nausea was the big issue with chemo and now the docs give you anti-nausea meds, so I expected to feel bad maybe the day of and after treatment. I had no idea how rotten you feel and for how long, That said, today's a good day. My DH and I are going to try for lunch and a movie. Thinking of you all!

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 12:05AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Good morning, ladies! Annie, I hope you're still symptom-free after your friend with strep was chased out of town. Good for you! I agree with everyone else's recommendations -- wash anything she touched in really hot water, use antiseptic wipes on all surfaces (light switches, toilet handles, doorknobs, too), air out the place. HeatherB, speaking of germs, how are you feeling today? Sore throat worse? Have you called your MO?  Josie, good to hear from you. I'd wondered where you'd been hiding. Yes, you had your infusion on Monday, and I had mine on Tuesday. Funny you should mention being sensitive to noise. I find I'm more sensitive to both odors and noise. I've had to ask my DH to turn down the TV several times.  And I have to hide in the bedroom when he's cooking some of his dinners. I feel bad. I can't ask him to share my diet of baked potatoes and grilled cheese sandwiches, but my nose is VERY sensitive to herbs, spices and such. Also glad you're getting acupuncture. I go every 2 weeks. Ecpelkey, sorry to hear about your fluid beneath the SNB scar. That's a weird one, isn't it? And I felt for you when you said everyone in your household was sick on Thursday and Friday. Ckk, I tend to agree that some of us just have a genetic disposition to cancer. Both my parents died of cancer -- lymphoma for my dad, who was just 56, then both colon and lung cancer for my mom. I had colon cancer 14 years ago and have had numerous Mohs surgeries for basal-cell skin cancers (luckily not melanoma, like you had).  My heart races, too. I hear my blood pumping in my ears all the time.  GracieG, my acupuncturist swears by lemon as well, not specifically for cancer but for overall health. She says if she were on a deserted island, the only two things she would want would be lemon and honey. At her suggestion, I've been trying to drink several glasses a day of hot water with lemon. I've been having trouble getting enough liquids and, for some reason, the hot liquids go down more easily than the cold. I just put a glass of water with lemon in the microwave for about a minute. Overall, I've been able to handle sour tastes much more than anything else. I still can't eat sweets or salty foods. Hope everyone has a good day. Who has treatments this week?

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 07:55AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Josie, good to hear from you and to know your last infusion went well. I had my Neulasta shot yesterday and am off in an hour for acupuncture. I'm a believer, too. I'm also a gardener -- mostly flowers, shrubs and some fruit trees. Ckk, we're with you today!!! Can't wait to hear from you tonight. Hope everything goes smoothly.  I know this is an old gripe, but our discussion of leg and muscle pain reminds me of how little people who haven't been through this understand. So many of my friends assume that hair loss and nausea are the only side effects I have had to deal with. Nobody knows the other agonies you and I have been through -- constipation, diarrhea, thrush, mouth sores, night sweats, hot flashes, acid reflux, racing heartbeat, loss of taste and appetite, sour taste and tummy, insomnia, dry skin, pimples, forgetfulness, irritability, depression, weight gain, dehydration, fevers, bone and muscle pain, extreme fatigue, blown veins, bruises, emotional ups and downs. Hopefully, most of that is behind us now, except for the continuing and frustrating fatigue and bone and muscle pain. We are wounded warriors. We are strong women who have endured these agonies. We will come out of this stronger still. We will vow not just to have our "old lives" back but to have new and better lives because of what we've been through, what we know. We will cherish every day of good health. We will not take things for granted. And we will remain friends for years to come!!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2012 05:10AM - edited Mar 27, 2012 05:11AM by WaveWhisperer Hi, ladies, I told myself I wasn't going to read it, but I finally started "The Emperor of All Maladies," a history of cancer. There are definitely things in the book I wish I hadn't run across, but the brutal history of earlier surgical and chemical treatments certainly makes me glad we were treated in 2011 and 2012, not the '50s, '60s or '70s. One thing I read just a bit ago did certainly ring true with the emotions many of us have felt: "Cancer is not a concentration camp (referring to something earlier) but it shares the quality of annihilation: it negates the possibility of life outside and beyond itself; it subsumes all living. The daily life of a patient becomes so intensely preoccupied with his or her illness that the world fades away. Every last morsel of energy is spent tending the disease." That supports the feeling of aloneness, of alienation that we all have felt at various times.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 09:26AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Hi, Ladies! Ckk, thanks for asking about me. I haven't been posting in a while, but I'm fine. In fact, I feel so good, so much better that I just didn't want to think about cancer for a while. I woke up one morning recently, after a terrific night's sleep -- no night sweats -- and realized that something felt different. My hip aches and burning thighs were gone. Just like that. Here one day, gone the next. And rads have been a breeze. After 10 treatments, I don't feel a thing, not even a hint of pink.  I also had company for a week, and they just left yesterday. My sister and her husband came to visit to "take care of me," but we ended up having a wonderful visit, doing all sorts of touristy things here in Charleston. We ate out a lot, I had my first wine in 6 months, and I walked a lot, even though I had to stop and rest regularly. Jen: I'm sorry I'm late to the game in congratulating you on your successful surgery and your grit in making that tough decision. The surgery sounds like a real ordeal, with a full 15 hours of surgery and then blood transfusions and the IV problems. I'm glad you're feeling good enough to post, and I sincerely wish you a smooth recovery.  Rachel, thinking about you this weekend, too, and hoping the low point after your last infusion isn't too bad. Just take it a day at a time, and those SE will soon be behind you. Leesa, I applaud you and Ckk for your bike-riding. I'm wondering whether that's something I should consider...easier on the knees and hips and I still am plagued by plantar fasciitis (sp?). I was in PT for that last October when I got my BC DX, so I immediately quit. I had bigger issues to deal with. Despite the upturn in my physical condition, I have the same fears and concerns others of you have expressed. I love Momof3's idea about the shower scanner!!! I wish we could have more aggressive monitoring. I know I will worry about every new ache and pain. Already I'm worrying about a pain in my left breast, the GOOD one. But I have to keep telling myself that I had a BMRI six months ago and that everything was OK then, and since then I've had chemo. And I know there are legions of BC survivors out there, some of my friends and relatives among them. But every day I read obits in the paper for women in their 40s, 50s and 60s who have died from breast cancer. My gut hurts when I read that phrase: "so-and-so died after a courageous 3-year battle with breast cancer." Our local newspaper and TV stations did feature stories on a local 5th grade teacher, wife of a radio talk show host, who had BC, underwent all the treatments and returned to work, only to have it "return with a vengeance," as her husband said, 2 years later. She died at 44, leaving a 9-year-old son. These are the stories that haunt me. Stories of women who did everything we did and have cancer come back so aggressively and so quickly. I just have to tell myself, over and over, that I have done everything I can do to deal with it, and I have to live my life. I'm going to do everything I want to do. I'm not going to put off anything. I don't want to have any regrets today, tomorrow or whenever. Cancer either will or won't come back, no matter what I do. My MO told me that many women experience feelings of doubt and loss after chemo and rads. They feel "let go" from their medical support system. There is something reassuring about having all these nurses and doctors see us every few weeks, about having our blood work done regularly, about something listening to our hearts and lungs, about someone asking us if there's anything new or different. It was also reassuring to know that if something even non-BC related came up, there was a doctor to call about it. If I needed a prescription for anything, the MO was there to give it to me. I think there ought to be more support systems for those of us at this stage of our recovery. There might be threads on this topic here on bc.org, but I haven't checked. At least we're all here to help each other. And you're right...we've been through so much...we've come so far... you all mean so much to me!!! I'm off for more activities today with my daughter and her family. Hope everyone has a good Sunday! Love you all!!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 07:19AM - edited Dec 23, 2011 07:22AM by WaveWhisperer Ckk, I'd been wondering how you fared with your first treatment. Sounds like you did great. Like you, I didn't sleep at all the first night. You're right -- the steroids, as both nurses and patients told me. Lisa, welcome to the world of hot flashes! I went through menopause naturally some years ago, but the ones I'm having now, as a result of dropping my hormone replacement therapy, are quite a bit more vicious. They really are annoying. One of my nurses said, "We can put a man on the moon, but we don't know how to alleviate hot flashes!" She said two triggers are chocolate and red wine, which just happen to be two of my vices.  Thanks to everyone for their advice and support. I'm 3 days out from my first T/C and feeling a bit low. I want my old life back! The road ahead is long, and I've just started. Right now, I can't see the light at the end of this tunnel. Here I am, feeling not my best at the holiday and waiting for my hair to fall out. Still, things could be worse, right? Hope everyone has a good day and a good holiday!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 12:05AM - edited Dec 27, 2011 12:10AM by WaveWhisperer Michelle, welcome to the club. I think, you, CKK, Josie and I all are on the same T/C schedule. I had my first infusion 12/20, with Neulasta the next day. I was queasy the first few days and achy after the Neulasta, but Claritin and Alleve help, as well as long soaks in the tub. I have no appetite whatsoever, and it's a struggle to try to find anything I want to eat. My lovely family gave me TONS of chocolate candy for Christmas, but I can't eat even one piece. The not-so-lovely diarrhea has hit me hard. I was expecting the opposite, so stocked up on all kinds of laxatives. What's best for this?? Other than that, I'm just tired, with no energy. I sleep a lot now, after no sleep the first two nights. Wednesday, I go for Haircut #1, my first short haircut since I was a teen-ager. That's the precursor to the buzz cut. Like others, I'm wondering whether treatments #2, #3 and #4 will have even more dramatic side effects. Are the effects cumulative?  Betsy, thanks for the TOOLBOX idea. That's my next stop. Hope EVERYONE had a good holiday. At least we made it through it, even though it might have been different from all our others. If you were like me, you were especially appreciative of family and friends. A few days before Christmas, I wrote a dear friend whom I had grown distant from after her husband developed dementia. At the time, I didn't know what to say, so I withdrew and said nothing. Now I'm seeing the same behavior from a few of my friends. I felt bad about my own behavior and apologized to her in a long "confession." On Christmas Eve, she called, told me that we'd always be friends. It was the best present ever!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 08:28AM WaveWhisperer wrote: TODAY I am feeling....still lousy! Loulabell, that's a really great idea -- to put up a sign so everyone knows immediately what kind of day it is. CKK, I think you're right about people's true colors showing in times like this. The givers continue to give, the takers continue to do their thing. There's one woman in my neighborhood whom I've just known less than a year. She e-mails me to tell me that she's coming over to water and trim my plants. When she's outside, she will bring up the newspaper and the mail. She dedicated her "Walk for the Cure" -- all 38 miles -- to me. And I have a sister, my only sister, who has sent me one card. I'm the one who calls her to see how SHE is (and she's perfectly healthy). And she goes on and on about these wonderful meals she and her husband have been cooking, when the mere thought of food makes me queasy. I know that from now on, I will be a better friend to anyone who's going through this. I've already apologized to one friend, who had BC, chemo and rads 6 years ago. At the time I was her boss. I thought I was being understanding at the time, but now I cringe at how little I did or felt. I didn't know there were a hundred different kinds of BC; all I knew was that there was a Stage 1, which was good, and Stage 4, when you probably wouldn't make it. I never made the effort to really talk to her about what she was going through. As for me, I can't seem to bounce back from T/C #2, one week ago. I tried running one errand this morning -- my first trip out since #2 -- and it exhausted me. I'm back in bed. Still no appetite and that horrible taste in my mouth.   Did someone else say their hair is sticking around? I had my head buzzed about 2 weeks ago, but all the buzz is still there, and I still have my body hair. I thought all of that would be long gone by now. Someone is having a treatment tomorrow -- Josie? Momof3? Anyway, hugs to you --  and all of you.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 12:35AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Bailey and Momof3, thinking about you and sending a warm blanket and a big hug as you go off to your treatments today. Heatherb, you are so smart to plan a family trip to Disney World after your treatment, We all need something to look forward to, to help us mentally get through these dark days. My husband and I just yesterday started thinking about a trip to Barcelona for next fall. Just researching hotels yesterday onllne kept me busy, my mind off my yuckiness. And I do think we should plan a girls' get-together after our treatments are over. Wouldn't that be wonderful? Again, even if it fell through, the planning would be something positive. Ckk, I, too, don't think anyone is "blocking" a cure to cancer, but it certainly is frustrating that we've made so little progress. A TV show the other night marked the 40th anniversary of the US government's "Fight Against Cancer." My dad died of cancer 44 years ago, when he was in his early 50s. Still today there's no cure for the cancer that killed him. I Googled it and they're still using the same lousy chemo drug now that they used on him 45 years ago. There's also no cure for the common cold. We've made much progress in cancer detection, and yes, the therapies and drugs have gotten more targeted, but why can't the best brains in the world figure this out? OK, that's my vent for today.  TODAY, I'm feeling...better. Day #8 after treatment #2, and I may have turned the corner. The mouth monster may have started creeping back into his cage, and the tummy tumbler may be taking a short nap. I'm still tired as heck, and depressed, but we'll take this thing one day at a time.  This is my greatest pleasure of each day, coming here to join with you friends. Every single one of you is a gift.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2012 11:49PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Ckk, yes I like the idea of posting our treatment dates. One way to do that would be to edit our profiles, so that treatment dates show up with our DX. Anyway, mine are: 12/20, 1/11, 1/31 and 2/21. Erica, yes to the acne, too. Not as bad as when I was young, but still some unexpected pimples.  Annie, my scalp is itching like crazy this week, and I notice the prickly little hairs left from my buzz cut are dropping out. Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 12:35AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Ecpelkey, if your MO says he could give you the Neulasta shot, I'd try it next time. It's supposed to help boost your white and red (right, girls?) blood count and help your body's defenses, especially around mid-cycle of your treatments. I get one after each infusion. The most common side effect from the shot itself is body aches. My MO explained that it's because the medicine goes to your bone marrow. Most of us get relief by taking Claritin and Tylenol before and after the shot. Momof3boys (Joyce), I, too, am sorry you had such a rough day. I know exactly how you feel. The very same symptoms hit me after both treatments #1 and #2, but hit me harder and more quickly after #2. I have to admit I felt so bad I stayed in bed for 2-3 days. Just hang in there and know that this, too, will pass and today, tomorrow or the next day, you'll start to feel better.  BTW, I also was wondering the same thing about the ladies taking steroids at home. I just get them in my IV. I don't take them by mouth either before or after treatment. I just have Zofran and compazine for nausea. Are those steroids? Lisa, Madison and Heatherb, I'm jealous of your being almost through this. You will graduate from the December thread. Please don't leave the rest of us behind. Come visit us. Prop us up. Cheer us on. We don't want to lose you. We need to stay in touch so we can ALL celebrate when the very last one of us is through. Seriously, you do give us hope and you've all been such a help to us. We're very proud of your having done this. Kudos to Lisa, especially, for starting this thread, which has meant so much to us. Lisa, Annie and others, I think we all are angry at having to go through this and upset when well-meaning family, friends and colleagues don't understand how awful this can be. It's especially hard on those of you still with hair. You "look" normal and well, and many of you still manage to work through this. All those things are a testament to your own strength, commitment to the labor-intensive cold-cap treatments and advances in chemo. As Gracie said, before I had chemo myself, I had NO IDEA what people were going through. I look back and regret how mistaken I was in dealing with a dear friend and a sister-in-law who had BC. I thought that infusion day or maybe 1 day after was rough for them; I had NO IDEA how crappy they were feeling for weeks afterward.   Even I was naive about my own treatments. In the beginning, I looked at the calendar and said, "Great, my last infusion is 2/21, so I can start rads that week and be through with everything by a particular date." Now I know that the infusion is just the start of the bad times, that it takes a good 3 weeks to feel "almost normal."  I, too, wonder if I ever will feel "normal" again. With treatment #3 coming up Tuesday, I feel good this weekend, but there's still this cloud hanging over me, counting the few days left when I will feel good, dreading the days after #3, wondering whether they will be better or worse. I'm not sure knowing what's to come helps or hurts.  As someone said on one of these forums, find joy in today! Hugs to all!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 11:41PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Good morning, ladies! Gracie, yes, yes, my sleep patterns have changed dramatically. All my life I've been a good sleeper, at sleep at 10 and awake at 6. Now every night is a struggle. Sometimes I'm still awake at 12, 1, 2, even 3. Other nights I'm asleep by 9 but awake, as I was this morning, for an hour or so about 4 am. And sometimes this is even with a sleeping pill. During the first 10 days after treatments, I can hardly stay awake during the day, but nap for only 10-15 minutes at a time. Frustrating. Robin, glad your foot is no worse, Lisa, I'm so sorry you're in a black hole right now. You will crawl out of it. You're our leader, remember??? We're counting on you to tell us what life is like on the other side -- the other side of chemo!! Your last one was 1/31, the day of my 3rd. I'm hoping to feel better tomorrow, which will be Day #10. I'm mentally going to cede 10 days of feeling bad but then concentrate on feeling good for the next 10 days.  It was so sweet of the vet's office to send you the lovely plaque in Daisy's memory. I think our emotions get whacked with the chemo, just like everything else. I got teary at the Camry ad during the Super Bowl.  But you probably would have reacted the same way, even without chemo. You're still grieving, still raw, missing her so much.   Madison, good to hear you're on the upswing. Karen and Heather, the hot flashes have been terribly annoying, especially during the night, accompanied by night sweats. These are far worse than anything I had during menopause. I think I posted earlier that my BS told me that red wine and chocolate can be two triggers for hot flashes, and I have to say they've backed off since I eliminated those two favorite vices.  HeatherB and others, this fatigue is so much more debilitating than I ever imagined. It's more than being tired or sleepy. Even walking short distances leaves me panting. The lethargy, too. Sometimes I will lie in bed for almost an hour, just delaying getting up to go to the bathroom. I will sit in a chair, motionless, for 15-20 minutes before I force myself to get up. I'm beginning to hate my bed and my bedroom, but really all I feel like doing is crawling into bed. BTW, my MO's office called yesterday about my neuropathy, also referred to as Hand and Foot Syndrome on this site's treatment and side effects page. The nurse said it's a definite SE from the Taxotere. She said for me to monitor it and call again if it started interfering with my daily life, like keeping me from walking. She said the MO will consider whether or not to give me less T in my upcoming treatment. She said it should start going away after treatment. Guess that's it for now. Hope everyone has a decent day. My goal is to, like one of you said, get out of the house and walk for 15 minutes.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 10:45PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Ckk, I loved picturing you and your girls making goodies for her college mates. I think we tend to think about my BC less when we're busy, doing something with others.  As for changes in taste, SO TRUE!!! I am a dyed-in-the-wool chocoholic, and everyone who knows me knows that about me. For Christmas, I received boxes and boxes of chocolate -- Godiva, See's, imported chocolate from Belgium, Ghiradelli, moose munch, chocolate-covered peanuts, Philadelphia. That was just around my first chemo treatment. I have not eaten ONE PIECE of chocolate in 2 months. I can't abide the thought of chocolate. Right now it's as if someone offered me a raw onion. I also steer clear of anything tomato-based, probably because I had such bad acid reflux one night after having tomatoes for lunch and dinner. Before, I loved tomatoes. During my worst days, as I may have mentioned before, all I can stomach are white and yellow foods -- a baked potato, a scrambled egg, pasta with Parmesan, mac and cheese. Even as my appetite and taste buds come back a little, I still tend to want mostly carbs -- bread and pasta. No one told me to avoid my favorite foods while in chemo, but I can understand the logic. A lifetime ago, when I was in college, I had my worst hangover ever after drinking a coconut-flavored drink (well, guess it was way more than one!). To this day, I can't stand the thought of coconut-flavored stuff. Even more amazing, when I was 5 or six, I got sick after drinking a grape drink. Same thing. I still can't drink grape drinks. Oh, well, enough of the "drinks I threw up from" memories!! Rachel, I just ordered a dozen pair of inexpensive white gloves from Amazon. I decided that's going to be one of my new defense techniques. I'm also going to sleep in them, with my hands lathered in some rich moisturizer. My skin is so dry! For years, my dermatologist has been trying to get me to wear gloves while driving. She says the hands get a lot of sun damage while you're driving, and my hands are proof of sun damage. I've had numerous precancerous spots frozen. As part of my defense strategy, I also ordered 100 individually wrapped GermX wipes, which I'm going to take with me to the grocery, drugstore, etc. because not all stores offer wipes for the cart handles. At the "LGFB" class, they also said wipes are good to clean out germs from under our fingernails, which plain hand sanitizer probably doesn't do. And speaking of shopping, I saw a recommendation on another thread here about Lindi skin products, designed specifically for cancer patients. I ordered the facial kit, which includes cleanser, moisturizer and eye cream. I think it's already helping. Most of my pre-chemo products were anti-aging ones (Olay, etc...), and they were way too drying for my now-paper-thin skin. I ordered Lindi online, but the shop where I bought one of my wigs also carries it. Madison, I'm so sorry to hear about your friend's violation of your trust. I think you're right. A person who will gossip to you also will gossip about you; it's just their nature. I've had a friend or two like that. For some insecure people, information is power. It's the currency they use to try to get people to like them. I had to distance myself from these friends and "downgrade" the friendship to one where I would never share anything personal that I didn't want broadcast. My "good week" continues. Last infusion a week from tomorrow. And I'm calling the MO this morning about my vaginal lump. Hey, Happy early Valentine's Day to all of you. I'm been telling all my other friends about you, about our friendship, our bond. Coming to know you, to share our darkest fears, our anger, our frustrations, our accomplishments has been the single best thing about this disease. We have shared things with each other we haven't shared with our spouses, partners, siblings. What an incredible group this is. You are my special Valentines in a year we will never forget. I love you all!

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 11:11PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Ckk, interested in your rads starting 3/19, since we're basically on the same chemo schedule. I went up to the desk and quietly told them I was a cancer patient, in chemo, and asked whether I could wait somewhere else than the waiting room. And I continue to be in awe of how active you've remained through all this. Have you missed work at all, except for infusion days?? Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 11:38PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Karmil, so sorry to hear you have strep, but good for you for getting to the doctor quickly and getting started on antibiotics. Hope you start feeling  better soon. Lisa, happy to know the sniffles, runny nose and hot flashes are gone. That's a good sign for the rest of us. And you're right about our recovery and spring both being on track. My acupuncturist said the same thing, that spring is the natural time for regrowth, recovery, recuperation. I guess if we had to go through all this crap with hibernating, wearing wigs and staying in bed, winter was a good time to experience it. Now we all can really look forward to feeling better and taking advantage of nicer weather.  Gracie, enjoy your night out at the BB game. I actually played college BB for a year and still enjoy every minute of March Madness.  Baileybump, will be crossing all my fingers and toes for a good report from the home inspector!  Rachel, enjoy your visitors from Russia. Weeks ago, I posted something to you on FB about Russia, but I was new at posting and it didn't show up. My husband worked as a journalist in Russia back in the early '90s, and I went over there to drag him home. We took the overnight train from Moscow down to Yalta and even managed to sneak into Sevastopol. I just finished reading "Catherine the Great," which was marvelous. Ckk, hope you have a better day and night tonight. Yesterday, 3 days PFC, was one of my worst days ever -- fever of 100.1, body aches from head to toe, muscle spasms, queasiness, "south mouth," as you said. I stayed in bed all day, napping for 15 minutes, then waking up to repeat the cycle.  Happy to report that I woke up feeling much better today.  Ckk, jealous of you girls who were brave enough to do cold caps. Now that chemo is over, you have HAIR!! I was worried that inches of white roots would be worse than no hair at all, but now I wish I had had the gumption to try them. It will be years before my hair is back to its former length.. Oh, well.... Have a good weekend, friends!

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 10:46AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Momof3, I also got sick of people asking me, "Aren't you excited about your last treatment?" and "How are you going to celebrate?" I told them I was relieved the treatments were coming to an end, but I didn't feel like "celebrating" because it was more like being released from prison or having torture ended. And I knew that I still had 10 days of feeling miserable facing me. Happily, though, I seem to be rebounding from TC#4 more quickly than the others, especially #3. Like Robin, I keep trying to clean my glasses. I've had to increase the type size on my Kindle, and I've found it really hard to real magazines, even with glasses.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 04:59AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Joyce posted on FB that she's through with today's infusion!!! Just got back from the derm appointment. I had that scheduled anyway but used the opportunity to ask about this redness spreading out from my IV site. She didn't think it was phlebitis but was worried about it and got me started on antibiotics. She doesn't want me to get a blood infection. I stopped by the MO's office on the way home to show the nurse, and, she, too, was puzzled, said she'd never seen anything like it. Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 11:49PM - edited Mar 3, 2012 11:51PM by WaveWhisperer Bailey, thanks for more detail about rads. All of us getting ready for that are interested in what's ahead. But NO SWIMMING???? I'd never thought of that. Do you know why? Rachel, I would definitely pursue that temporary handicapped permit.  I've looked enviously at all those handicapped parking spots as I've trudged by, huffing and puffing.  I spent a good deal of time last night checking the Internet for anything about contaminated Taxotere or skin reactions. There was a spate of postings in 2011 about a possible "bad batch" of Taxotere made overseas, but I couldn't find anything from anyone other than patients. I found more, however, about delayed skin reactions from Taxotere, including a posting from a nurse who said she had something like 4 patients in 2 weeks who had delayed skin reactions -- from 7 to 10 days out -- from T.  Skin reactions also are listed as a "rare" side effect on Taxotere's long info sheet. And I found one woman's blog with a photo of her hand that looked EXACTLY like mine. In her blog, she also said her hand hurt, which mine does. She said hers was from Taxotere. Mine is slightly better today, although it's the same size as before. I know doctors sometimes pooh-pooh all the stuff on the Internet -- and I agree that a lot is pure bull -- but I'm going to tell my MO what I've found. I'm going to the circus today! My daughter and her husband are taking my two grandsons, 1 and 5 years, to their first circus, and I'm tagging along just to see the 5-year-old's reaction. It always reminds me of the time we took my daughter to the circus, in Norfolk, VA, on a late March or early April Saturday in 1980 or so. We went to the 11 am performance and it started snowing as we left. The people who attended the 3 pm performance that day didn't get out for 2 DAYS!! The biggest snowstorm in a century hit and the governor prohibited anyone from being on the roads. There were hundreds of families with not enough diapers or food or milk stuck in an arena with circus animals.   Well, hope everyone has their own kind of adventure this weekend!

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 12:48PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Have you ever woken up in the morning and immediately knew that something was different? That happened to me this morning. I woke up, opened my eyes, stretched in bed and knew something was different. I sat on the side of the bed and pondered this strange sensation. I felt GOOD! It was so dramatic and so meaningful that I just had to write about it. I wish I could adequately describe the difference between how I felt yesterday and every day since the last infusion with how I felt today. My mouth felt almost normal, my mind seemed clear and there was an absence of the "crud" feeling that has shadowed me since #4. I even had energy. Still short of breath, but I yanked off all the flannel sheets, washed them and replaced them with cotton. I was a white tornado. It was an amazing change. I hope I never have to feel that old bad feeling again. The circus was fun, but it was enough to make me get a handicapped parking sticker first thing Monday morning. I rode with my daughter and her family. It was pouring rain, really heavy. Traffic was clogged and we were among the latecomers. We had to park in an overfill lot a LONG way from the coliseum. They were walking fast, both because we were late and because it was raining so hard. I could not keep up. I had to stop several times on the way, making them -- including a babe in arms -- wait in the rain until I could get my breath. I was so embarrassed and mad. Please keep reassuring me that this will get better, that this isn't a sign of some sort of lung or heart problem. Ckk, I'm sorry you freaked out about the phlebitis and a connection to the Taxotere. How nice and comforting that you got such a caring and considerate MO on call. Rachel, now we know that you really are human :) You were keeping up such a pace, we thought you were the Bionic Woman, the woman who wasn't phased by chemo. You worked, you played in an orchestra, you guided guests around Philly while some of us couldn't get out of bed. Now you have hired someone to clean your digs and have admitted that chemo has indeed slowed you down. Of course, you soon got up from the couch and took a walk!!  Erica, I was quite impressed that someone from MD Anderson got back with you. It was very informative.  Robin, again this thing about "generic" Taxotere possibly causing problems....I'm definitely going to ask my MO.... Sleep well, friends!

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 07:15AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Rachel, last one tomorrow!!!! We're holding out a banner for you to run through at the end of tomorrow's treatment. Most of us who had 4 treatments are in awe that you've been able to get through six. We all have our fingers crossed that the SE are no worse than before. Mine weren't as severe, just lasted longer. Karmil, so glad you're doing well after surgery. And I just an hour ago finished "Emperor of all Maladies." Some of it is so technical -- talking about cells and genomes -- that I just skimmed those parts. Much of it is fascinating, especially parts about the doctors and scientists who were relentless and refused to give up experiments and theories that were pooh-poohed by their colleagues. The treatments we're receiving are so much more refined than they were, because of endless trials and experiments by these dedicated scientists. But there still is SO MUCH they don't know about cancer. One part mentioned a single slide from one woman's breast cancer that showed 13 different gene mutations. Even doctors wondered, "Will we have to come up with 13 different drugs to attack each one?" The book portrays cancer cells as ingenious, slippery, able to become resistant to some drugs, able not just to slide from one organ to another but to LEAP from one to another. The book says some small breasst cancers, even caught early, are highly aggressive and some very large breast cancers are indolent and lazy. It says some cancers will metastasize no matter what treatment doctors use, and others will NOT metastasize, even if nothing is done. So we all, and our doctors, are gambling. It's the best we can do. Some of us will never have another problem; others will have a recurrence, no matter how aggressive our treatments. It's not a book to read for entertainment. But I talked with my RO about it today, and she said even she had learned some things from the book, especially about the history of cancer and treatments. Karmil, speaking of "weird people," I had a woman stop her car in the middle of the road when she saw me walking "topless." She gave me a hug, said her mother had had BC and survived, then she showed up at my house a few days later with photos which she said showed my face in the clouds, a sign that God would heal me. And a woman at the gym who saw me topless stopped my car and told me that i HAD to stop conventional treatment and go with stuff from Mexico and the Far East, that her relative had been cured only after going to a clinic in Mexico... I think it's safer wearing my wig!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 09:03AM WaveWhisperer wrote: That's an excellent idea. Those of us who went through T/C in December 2011 found so much support from each other, since we all were going through it together. Talking with others who are on the same schedule as you will become an important part of your treatment, I guarantee you. Still, here are a few tips from one who went through it a year ago: 1) Drink water, water and more water. After my first infusion, I couldn't stand the taste of any liquid, even water. As a result, I got dehydrated and had to go back in for IV liquids. I tried every sports drink out there and still didn't like the taste. Everyone's different, but ultimately I lived on lemonade and sliced lemons in a glass of water, either cold or hot. 2) If Neulasta is offered to you, take it. It's a shot you get the day after your infusion and it helps build up those white cells that get killed off during chemo. The shot helps your immune system. It can create bone pain, but that's relieved by taking Claritin. 3) Listen to your body, and don't push yourself. You may find that there are certain days in your chemo cycle when you feel really bad. For many of us, fatigue was the worst side effect. Surprisingly, the new drugs they give you before the chemo allieve most of the nausea. When you get that "hit by a bus" feeling, just stay in bed and take it easy.  Read, watch videos... Gradually, you'll feel better, until that next round of T/C. After your first infusion, you'll notice what your own cycle is like. I kept a journal every day. 4) That said, if you're able to get some exercise when you feel like it, it will make you feel better. Some felt good enough to continue going to the gym; some of us just managed a slow walk around the block. 5) Have a family member or friend go with you to all doctor appointments, if possible. They can take notes and remember what the doctor says, sometimes better than you can. I also wrote out my questions for the surgeon and medical oncologist beforehand. 6) Again, every person is different, but you will probably have your own set of side effects, whether they're gastro-intestinal (constipation or diarrhea or heart burn) or dermatological (dry skin, nail problems) or sensory (numbness or tingling in fingers, toes or feet, hearing your heartbeat in your ears), and the inevitable insomnia. There is a drug out there for every side effect, and you'll end up taking more pills than you ever imagined. Don't hesitate to call your MO's office about anything that develops. Become friends with your infusion nurses and get their direct numbers. I called mine MANY times to ask about various things. Likewise, if your medical team includes a nurse coordinator, they are lifesavers! 7) Remember that your treatments WILL END. This is just one phase of your treatment. During chemo, you may wonder if you'll ever feel good again. You WILL!!! Along the way, though -- to bring this full circle -- nothing is more helpful than a group of women who are going through this at the same time. Get that new thread started, and watch the magic happen!! Some of these women will become your friends for life. Good luck. Its a tough journey, but you will get through it.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 08:16AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Bailey, glad #3 went well. Like the others, I loved your story about the author giving you his book. I think people come into our lives, or we come into theirs, for a reason. God's angels. During this rough struggle of ours, we encounter some beautiful moments. Yesterday, for instance, I went to the grocery store for the first time in 10 days. I wore a wig. My first stop was at the bakery counter, where I asked for a special loaf of bread behind the counter. The clerk said, "Oh, your hair is so beautiful." I wasn't sure what to say, but I told her about my cancer, and she cried and took my hand. She told me her sister had had it and was doing great. She wanted to know my name and said she would pray for me. Now I have a new friend, Michele. In October, my husband and I were planning a bathroom renovation. I made an appointment with the designer who had done our kitchen several years ago. I told her I'd come to her office. No, she said, she wanted to come to the house. The appointment was the day after my biopsy. My husband still was out of the country, on his way home. When the designer sat down, I started crying and told her I was waiting for biopsy results. We prayed and talked. Then the phone rang. Breast cancer. I know she was with me at that time for a reason. Gracie, I'm a huge Panera fan, too. My DH gave me a Panera card in my stocking at Christmas and the other day, on one of my first days out since the last treatment, I picked up Panera's mac and cheese and a loaf of cinnamon raisin bread to bring home. Comfort food. I keep writing Panera to tell them to open a store near me. And I'm on T/C despite a low Oncotype score, an 8. The MO recommended it because of my positive node. Josie,  I applaud you for thinking of having a portrait done as a bald woman. Right now, I can't stand to look at myself in a mirror, and only my DH has seen me bald. My appetite has been so erratic during chemo that it's all I can do to get something down; I have to admit my choices have not been healthy ones.  Like you, giving up sugar would be really hard for me. I like sweet tea and all kinds of desserts. I'm not a great cook, but I like to bake. How do you know which websites and articles are legitimate, or backed by real science? On the web, one can say anything is true, when it's not always. How do you eliminate sugar?? Ckk and others, what are you going to do about alcohol? I had just started drinking red wine about a year before DX for the heart benefits (I've always like white wines), but I gave up both during chemo. I think I could live without alcohol, but should I?  And, like others, my skin is so dry it's pitiful. I looked in a magnified mirror the other day and was horrified to see how much deeper and more extensive my wrinkles are, especially around the eye and neck. I look about 80! I wonder whether any of that will reverse itself after chemo... Speaking of skin, I'm wondering whether after all these treatments I will be so happy to be alive and feeling good that I don't care about wrinkles or gray hair. Or will I go to the other extreme and want Botox, laser treatments and such to look my best after looking and feeling so awful all this winter? Before my DX, my dermatologist had suggested laser treatments for the extensive sun damage on my face, chest and hands. Very expensive, though, and, of course, all that went out the window after my DX. Anyway, I'm just wondering how I will feel. But one thing: isn't is good and healthy and positive to be thinking about something, anything AFTER this is over??? These are my very best days in the chemo cycle. Yesterday, my DH and I went out to lunch and then I went shopping for spring clothes for my grandsons. I even cooked dinner for the first time in 3 months!! (Sorry, I know some of you don't have the luxury of having a husband cook for you every night.) Days like that remind me that I will have a long string of good days once the final chemo is finished and the SE out of my system. Amazing how my mental attitude follows my physical state...feel lousy, think lousy thoughts...feel good, think more positively... Here's to a positive day for everyone!!

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2012 09:52AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Momof3, so happy that your scan was clear!!! Peace of mind is a wonderful thing.... Rachel, have you been able to reach someone about the thrush?? Lisa, sorry you're plagued by hot flashes, fatigue and burning muscles. I have all of those. And I, based on your recommendation, ordered the Anastasia brow kit online from Sephora, and I love it. So far I haven't had to use the stencils, but I can tell the brows are thinning.  Today's FOURTH AND FINAL chemo is over!!!! It went incredibly smoothly. My favorite nurse was there and got a vein on the first try. I went out to lunch with my daughter afterwards and then came home for a long Benadryl-induced nap. Someone --- not sure if if it was this thread or not -- had asked what I was going to ask my MO on today's visit. Here's what she said: --I may not feel like myself until about Memorial Day. It will take that long, or longer, to regain my strength and energy and recover from the chemo SE. She said for some women it takes 6 months. --She doesn't recommend any specific vitamins or supplements to speed up that process. She said I could take them if I wanted, but she isn't a big advocate. --She recommended Neurotin or Gabapentin (same thing) for the neuropathy. She didn't feel it was severe enough to warrant scaling back on the Taxotere today, as long as it was not interfering with my daily activities. She said she and another colleague wrote a grant proposal to study why and how chemo causes neuropathy, got a pat on the back but no money. She said they surmise that chemo affects the nerve coverings. --She said I WILL NOT have regular MRIs, X-rays and scans to detect any new cancer. (I have a feeling insurance companies have something to do with this.) She said they depend on patients, who know their bodies best, to speak up if they notice any abnormalities, and then the doctors will investigate. I will have mammograms every 6 months for about 2 years, which is reassuring. --She said there's no reason I can't travel (commercial air) between chemo and radiation because the Neulasta shots have kept my WBC up. --She said I don't need a lymphedema sleeve for flying and don't really need to worry about lymphema. She said it's much less prevalent now that they do SNBs instead of removing all lymph nodes. The chance of lymphedema is greater if you have 10 nodes removed than if you have 8 removed, even less if you have 6 or 5 removed. I had 3 removed. She said as a precaution, in normal circumstances, it might be wise to use the OTHER arm for blood work and pressure (NOW she tells me!!), but that, if it's an emergency, medical perssonnel should use either one. Anyway, sorry if this is TMI if none of you were the ones who asked.... Oh, Lisa, now I have a GOOD customer service story to offset the awful one yesterday. I ordered one of those edible arrangements of fruit to pick up early this AM to take to my infusion nurses. When I got there, they said the arrangement wasn't quite ready and asked if I could come back later?? I said no, I was on my way to a doctor's appointment and this was for the nurses. I told them I would wait in my car, since there were no chairs. A few minutes later, a woman brought the bouquet to my car, apologized profusely and handed me a box of a dozen huge chocolate-covered strawberries. She said they were free, to make up for my wait. OK!!!! Josie, did you finish today??? THought about you.... Can you tell the steroids have kicked in?????

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2012 11:09PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Ckk, I know exactly how you feel about transitioning from being a cancer patient to being just you. My DH has been in the house with me for 5 months, cooking every dinner for me, sitting through every appointment. I'm sending him away for a month, back to our house in the Bahamas, where we both usually spend each winter. I told him that he needs to get back to the life he loves, and his heart really is on the island. I told him that I need to be on my own a little, to regain my independence. I'll be in radiation while he's gone, but that's OK. I don't need him holding my hand for that. When some  very kind neighbors heard that my DH was going to be gone for a month, they sent me a beautiful, long e-mail, saying that he shouldn't worry, that they would take his place and would cook my meals for me, take me to my appointments and watch after me. I was touched, but also slightly offended that I was considered some kind of invalid, or, as you said, CKK, a "sick child."  I wrote them back that I would be happy to accept an occasional invitation to their home for a lunch or dinner, that I'd love to go for a walk or go to a museum, or just come by to chat. I said I wanted to be treated as a friend, not as a cancer patient. Like you, I'm private and independent, too. Before BC, my DH had never been to any kind of appointment with me. I think you said the right thing to your DH. Maybe you can try to talk to him again about it, and make it more general, telling him all of us are going through this, struggling to find ways to move from being a cancer patient to being our old selves. Some of us are throwing out clothes we wore during chemo. Some of us are cleaning out whole closets of clothes from our "old lives" and starting anew. Some of us are vowing to lead healthier lifestyles. What you're asking of him is a part of this transition. You could not have made it through surgery and chemo without him. He's been there for you every step of the way. He's been sort of your "training wheels," helping to support your bumpy ride. Now you need to try to ride on your own.

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2012 01:46PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Idon'tdosick, what was it about the rads consultation that scared you? After chemo, many of us don't fear radiation so much. I realize there are short-term side effects and possible long-term side effects, but I think it's worth it. That said, no matter what the doctors recommend, the final decision about surgery is up to you. I know several women who had Stage 0 DCIS and still chose BMX because they didn't want to have to worry about either radiation or local recurrence. We all have to make the right decision FOR OURSELVES. I had a friend who was in tears about an upcoming surgery because she didn't like her surgeon and didn't think he liked her but was the only surgeon doing that kind of surgery in her hometown. She was petrified and said it just didn't feel right. I went out on a limb and asked her to consider going out-of-state to a facility that did hundreds of that kind of surgery. It meant she and her husband had to stay in an extended stay hotel for a month. In the end, she was so happy she did it and has never stopped thanking me. Moral is: Do what feels right for you. No one will be inside your head and heart down the road other than you. If you proceed with the radiation, now that some of us will be taking that journey with you as well, just like we did with chemo. I had my tattoos Tuesday and should start rads in about 2 weeks. Good night, all!

My stylist said he will come to my house to buzz-cut me whenever I need it. I don't seem to be shedding, but I have to admit I haven't shampooed since I got it cut -- gross, I know!! -- because I assume lots may come out then. I hate my wigs, too; they look like Halloween costumes. I've never been a scarf person, so I imagine I'll use baseball caps and, like you, that bucket hat. I bought one of those halo wigs to wear under the hat. Isn't it unfair that this disease takes, or disfigures, the attributes that mark us as women, at least on the outside -- our breasts and our hair? Yesterday, I was going through a lot of women's magazines to throw them. It was amazing how many of the ads and the articles are irrelevant to us now. Pages and pages of hair color, mascara, shampoos, conditioners and styling products, tweezers, razors, nail polish, weight loss programs, athletic shoes to firm up your butt, a million creams to minimize wrinkles, a hundred tips on anti-aging. It made me sad, that none of that applies to me now. It made me angry that all I want to do now is AGE! Maybe, after we get through this, we're less superficial, we care less about how we look. Or maybe, we return, with gusto, to the cosmetic counter. Whatcha think? Ckk, how are you today???  Baileybump, I never realized that women used to get chemo for 2 years!!?? Can you imagine living like this for 2 years? That does make it seem like treatment has improved drastically.  Happy 2012, everyone!!

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 06:14AM WaveWhisperer wrote: HeatherWeather, I just wanted to second your recommendation about massages. The cancer center where I'm being treated offers discounted massages for patients -- just $45 for an hourlong massage by a trained oncologist masseuse. They even have a special table with a foam insert, that lowers, to accommodate your breasts (or lack of). I had a massage the day before my surgery and the day before my first T/C. I know it helps me relax and reduces anxiety. Research has shown that surgical patients recover more quickly from anesthesia after massage. I'm also getting acupuncture tomorrow, to see if that can help with SE.  I, too, would love some kind of celebratory get-together after all of this is over. I'm in Charleston, and it's a wonderful city to visit, but I'd be willing to fly anywhere to meet up. GracieG, I had to laugh when I read about your desire for comfort foods. Until a day or two ago, I had no interest in eating. It was all I could do to eat a scrambled egg or baked potato. When the appetite started creeping back, I told my husband I wanted mac and cheese. The next night I craved mashed potatoes and green peas. That was my New Year's Eve dinner

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 05:22PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Momof3, Just wanted to reassure you that nightsweats can indeed be a side effect of chemo. I went through menopause with minimal discomfort, then was put on hormone-replacement therapy. The day I received my BC DX, the doctor said to stop the HRT immediately. Cold Turkey. Throw the Pills Away. The hot flashes and night sweats I've had since then make menopause seem like a glass of lukewarm water. Several mornings a week I wake up to see puddles of clothes leading from the bathroom to the bed, pajama top, pajama bottom, panties, socks. It looks as if someone had a romantic midnight romp, throwing off their clothes as they jumped into bed with their lover. But no, the path leads the other way. It's just "chemo me" with another one of her night sweats!

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 03:24PM - edited Jan 17, 2012 03:25PM by WaveWhisperer Hi, fellow members of the "Sick and Tired..." Club...  Josie, I've had the bone pain for up to 6 days after the Neulasta shot. E.g., today's Day #5 after my last shot, and I'm still taking Claritin and 2 Alleve. How did some of you managed to get Vicodin?! I'm jealous!!! Heatherweather, yes, I have two scripts for past-treatmet nausea, the Zofran and Compazine. Same as Rachel. The Zofran bottle says to take for 2 days after treatment, but my MO said it's OK to take it longer, if needed. The MO added Emend to my IV this time, and it helps. I didn't know they came in a pill as well. As for eating ice cream, it tastes great on the way down, but it runs right through my system, giving me horrible gas pains and diarrhea. I'm taking Nexium and Immodium, but the milk products still don't cut it. Like Lisa, I love my DietCoke in the morning. But where I used to chug at least 2 before noon, now I can barely finish one of the tiny plastic bottles. But if I don't have it, I get a terrible migraine. It still doesn't taste right. I have been having the most luck with lemonade, as someone suggested. The tartness seems less offensive than anything sweet. Isn't it awful that we can't even abide water?? ECpelkey, the phenergan is a prescription anti-nausea pill, sometimes given for morning sickness and other nausea. I don't know its potency compared to Zofran and Compazine. I would see how it works for you and, if it doesn't, ask your MO for something stronger the next time. GracieG, I, too, am always perplexed about what to say when people ask, "How ARE you, dear?" My DH sends out regular e-mails to our friends to give them updates, and most of the replies come back with something like, "So glad you're doing SO WELL," or "Glad to hear the chemo isn't so bad!" I overheard him telling someone on the phone, "To look at her, you wouldn't know anything was wrong!" What universe is he in? I look like an alien and I feel like a poisoned dog. Annie, you're so right that we do have it easier than women who have been through chemo in the past. I read somewhere that some women had chemo for up to 2 years. And we all remember the movies and books about cancer patients puking their guts out. When I first talked to my MO, I told her I was more worried about nausea than losing my hair. I just can't stand being nauseous. (Goes back to childhood carsickness.) She told me that if I got nauseous, she and the pharmacist aren't doing their job.  In the future, women will look back on our chemo regimens as being barbaric, I imagine. They'll probably all take pills, keep all their hair and get some kind of supplement to boost their energy. Someday.... Hoping better days are ahead for all of us. Do you think the short, dark days of winter make us even more depressed during this?

She wants to be the source of information, like she's the most connected, the most popular, the one everyone turns to. When I was diagnosed, I told my husband that I was sending a group e-mail to ALL my friends at the same time, speciifcally so that this particular woman was NOT the source of information about my health. Since then, I've been careful not to share with her anything that others don't already know. I've even taken some perverse pleasure in sharing a few details with a few closer friends, so that, if anyone in one of those  groups asks about how I'm doing, it will be one of them, not the other friend, who has the latest information. Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 09:12AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Neli, I just wanted to chime in and echo what other ladies have said. I think we're all scared of chemo, especially the first treatment. I put my first one off a bit, worried that I wouldn't feel good enough to attend a special event. Then the MO scheduled it for the week before Christmas. I asked if we could put it off until after Christmas. She said no. Looking back, I'm glad she did, and I wish I had gone ahead and started chemo sooner, because I'd be closer to being finished now. Some treatment centers offer a "chemo school," to show you what it's like and acquaint you with the nurses and set-up. Other places will just walk you through it, if you ask your MO. Honestly, the treatments themselves are no big deal; it's the side effects we deal with later that cause us problems.  DEFINITELY take someone with you. I have taken my husband to EVERY doctor's appointment and chemo treatment, for physical and moral support, to ask questions that I forget to ask and to remember things the doctors have said that I forget. I don't have many friends in town, so you're lucky you do have friends who have offered. Take them up on it. Depending on the time of your treatment, you could go to lunch before or after. Or pack lunches and eat them during treatment. My husband and I both take Ipads with us, and we play each other on "Words with Friends." This is a scary journey, but you are not alone. These forums are a great source of information and support. You might also ask if there's a BC support group in your area, or your BS or MO may be able to put you in touch with another BC patient who has actually been in your shoes.  You'll do fine. Hugs,
