I met once with the oncology psychiatrist and was totally turned off by her, but maybe I'll try her again. Annie, I think the back spasms may be linked to the Neulasta shot, although my MO said it was an uncommon reaction.  Josie, I think we have the same mouth sensations. You did a good job of describing it as scalded or burned. Nothing tastes right.  CKK, I think you're right about the stomach acid and small meals. My MO put me on Nexium and Immodium yesterday, and already the gastric distress is better. I'm eating lots of bananas, toast and trying to eat small snacks several times a day. The past few days since Christmas were pretty miserable. The diarrhea, headaches, stomach cramps and back spasms were horrible. It was all I could do yesterday to get out of bed to get to the MO. The lab results were OK. "You look fine on paper," she said, "but, in person, you don't look so good!" She immediately suspected dehydration, because of the severe diarrhea and my inability to tolerate liquids. So she sent me back to the infusion suite for an IV transfusion of two bags of saline. After sitting with me for close to 3 hours, my DH said, "Don't you think it would just be easier to try to drink something?! The Nexium, the Immodium, the sleeping pill and the IV infusion did wonders, I'm happy to report. I feel almost normal today. By 8 am, I had run the dishwasher, put out recycling cans, brought in the newspaper and folded some laundry. This is from a woman who yesterday could barely get out of bed. Days like today give me hope that not every day will be a bad day! I got my hair cut short today, and even that wasn't so traumatic. So, again, thanks for propping me up when I was leaning really low!

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 07:29AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Annibell, I can understand how you and others feel about the categories possibly shifting with the Oncotype scores, but let me respectfully disagree with your comment about it "not being right to change the rules in the middle of the game." This cancer game, this breast cancer game, is an ongoing game, a seemingly never-ending game, one doctors and patients have been fighting for what, 50 years, 60 years, even longer? Many of us are alive today, will be alive 20-30 years from now, because of research done earlier which indeed "changed the rules." We're getting chemo drugs that weren't around 30 years ago. Many of us have sentinel node biopsies, whereas years ago, every lymph node would have been removed. Many of us have had breast-conservation surgery, whereas years ago a full mastectomy was automatic. Partial-breast irradiation is new. So is the Oncotype DX test itself. The BC patients who came before us made the best choices available to them at the time, although, with new advances, they, too, made have complained about the rules changing. Likewise, we're making the best choices for ourselves right now, even though, even six months from now, some protocols will be changing. We have to applaud anything that changes the rules because, hopefully, those changes will benefit those who follow us, if not us. SORRY for jumping on that and getting on my soapbox. I guess I'm just feeling feisty today. Please forgive! HEATHER, I know the prospect of a first surgery is scary. I've had four surgeries over the years. I can tell you that none of those surgeries, including a major abdominal surgery for colon cancer, was as rough as going through chemo. I would imagine many other women here would attest to the fact that even a BMX is easier to endure than what we're going through with chemo. My advice would be to concentrate on the outcome: that the surgeon is getting rid of your cancer, that this is a good thing, a TERRIFIC thing. You've been through the toughest part. Really.  APRIL, I ordered the "Cancer-FIghting Kitchen" from Amazon yesterday, so I'm eager to try some of the recipes. Thanks for suggesting it, as well as the coconut water. Now I'll have to get that whey powder, too.  MOMOF3BOYS, So glad you managed to get some sleep and that you're getting out, even in the cold, for a walk.  GRACIE, Welcome, too. I encourage you to take the Ativan, whenever you think you need it. Usually, I don't like taking too many drugs, but with this BC, I'm jumping at anything and everything that will make me feel better and alleviate these maddening side effects. I'm taking an anti-depressant every day, a sleeping pill every night and an Ativan as an additional calming agent when I need it. I have prescription Nexium and Immodium for the diarrhea that got out of control last week. I take Claritin and Tylenol before and after the Neulasta shots. I use Biotene mouth wash. I'm a walking pharmacy, even without all that chemo poison in my system. Yesterday was my best day yet since chemo #1 12 days ago. I felt almost normal, except for the lack of appetite and everything tasting like straw. Went for a walk, which was lovely. Hope everyone enjoys New Year's Eve in their own way. (I haven't seen midnight in a decade!)

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 09:05AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Lisa, hope the heat and Tylenol are helping the phlebitis. On the eyebrows, lashes, I have half an eyebrow over each eye and am beginning to notice gaps in the eyelashes, despite nightly use of a Latisse-like product. Went to the "Look Good, Feel Better" class today and the instructors had some warnings and tips I hadn't heard before, including: --At all costs, avoid waterproof mascara because it contains tar and over time will cause lashes to drop out. --During chemo and radiation, avoid having our hands soak in water and use gloves when washing dishes. They said soaking softens the skin too much and makes it more suspectible to infection. There go my long bubble-bath soaks! --When using hand sanitizer, make sure to clean under the nails. --Nail polish is OK and may prevent nails from cracking or getting too soft. But don't use acetone polish remover. --Use disposable mascara wands, eyeshadow brushes, etc. during treatments. It felt good to get out of the house, but this fatigue is incredible. I can't imagine how much weaker I will get after treatment #4. Have a call in to my MO about the neuropathy...pins and needles sensations in hands and feet, numbness in ball of one foot and tips of my fingers are becoming numb. Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 11:56PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Good morning, ladies! Karen, welcome to our group and congratulations on having had your last treatment! Erica, good luck today with your treatment #2. Wishing you plump veins and good blood results. Loulabell,  at the "Look Good, Feel Better" class yesterday, the instructor said we shouldn't use false eyelashes...something about the glue smothering the roots or something. But I have bought some, and I'm going to try them when my lashes are gone. Even with a wig, I think we look too "different" without brows and lashes. I've bought some brow stencils and powder, too. GracieG and Ckk, we're all in the same boat with the overwhelming fatigue and the frustration at not being our usual active selves. I saw myself in a mirror yesterday, at the hospital for that class, and, with my bald head and slow, shuffling walk, I looked like a hospital patient on her last leg. I wouldn't say this anywhere, except in the security of this forum, but my mind goes to dark places and I wonder if this is what it feels like in end-stage cancer. First you can't walk a mile, then you can't walk around the block, then you can't get out of bed, then you're in a wheelchair. You quit eating.  I really do try to stay positive. This is just such a horrible experience. My mind tells me that it's temporary, and I know from the two previous treatments, that I will feel better on or about Day #10. But while I'm in the worst of it, I feel and look like someone who is so sick. Sorry about that, ladies. Your regularly scheduled program will resume shortly!

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 11:27AM WaveWhisperer wrote: Good evening, ladies.  Rachel, had to laugh about your doctor calling your belly button unremarkable. I once had a brain scan and that's what the report said: "Brain unremarkable." I was mightily insulted, until the doc told me that was a medical term. Ckk and Heatherb8, welcome to the meltdown club. I think we all get to the breaking point at least once or twice during this. It all goes back to no one, not even our closest friends and family, really understanding how awful this is, physically and mentally. It's worse when we look OK (now when was that???) and try to keep up our old schedules. Those of you with jobs and kids at home don't have any way to avoid that.  Lisa, I think you're really feeling the effects -- good ones -- of not having another treatment ahead of you. I'm so glad you're experiencing this feeling of freedom and joy; I hope we all will be there soon. I always want to say the "glass is half full," but I have to admit that during my "good" week, I'm always dreading the next treatment. I'm 10 days away from my last infusion, so this should be my "good week." My taste buds are a little better. I'm still really tired but definitely better than the last week. However, I work up at 4 this morning to go to the bathroom and discovered this hard lump on one of my labia, something that wasn't there yesterday, something large under the skin almost like a piece of wood.  I cried and prayed and could not go back to sleep. I searched the entirety of this site and couldn't find any reference to anything like that. I decided I would call the on-call oncologist, but then, with daylight, decided that this wasn't like a fever, wasn't life-threatening for the next 48 hours, and I'll wait to call on Monday. But whom do I call - my MO or my GYN, whom I haven't seen since my DX?? Is this related to the neuropathy I'm having? Is it a tumor? (What are skin mets anyway?)  Why do we have to worry about all these other things while we're dealing with BC and chemo?? Will we always think the worst anytime we find any abnornality?  I decided to keep it all to myself and we went to my little grandson's 1st birthday party today. It was the first "event" I've been to since chemo. Did every child and their parent have a cold? YES!   And then there were the whispered words of concern and support. My daughter's MIL was there and said, "I hear it's a little bit like having the flu." Well, yeah, but not really. "I felt just like that when I was pregnant," she said, knowingly. I just nodded. Yeah, the flu. Plus headaches and nosebleeds; dry, itchy skin; constipation, diarrhea and hemorrhoids; no appetite; everything tastes like crap; anemia; hot flashes and night sweats; loss of all your hair; blurry vision; insomnia; acid reflux and heartburn; extreme fatigue; depression; pain in your hands and feet; sensitivity to smells and sounds; immune suppression; and on and on. As for the weather, even here, deep in South Carolina, it's supposed to be down in the low 20s tonight!!

My scalp itches like crazy...)  Karen, I think we all can relate to your movie misadventure. I feel as if I'm in a fog most of the time. The other night I asked my husband a question and then realized he had just answered the same question from me about 5 minutes earlier.  --What supplements should I take to help with the anemia, the neuropathy, with getting back my health and energy? (I stopped taking everything while in chemo...) What things should I avoid? (I know soy, e.g.)  --What kinds of scans will I have and how often from now on? (All I know of right now is the mammogram in May, about 6 months after DX and surgery...) --When will I start Arimidex? Will that be only after my rads or during? (And at some point I will have to break down and ask about the side effects from that...)  Part of my anxiety probably has to do with being "released," as CKK said, but not so much from chemo as from my MO, whom I adore. Both my BS and MO -- both women -- have been incredibly caring and have taken an inordinate amount of time answering all the questions my DH and I have had.  I trust them implicitly. I like them. I am in awe of their skill and intelligence.I wish I could see them forever. I've met my RO once, and I know I won't have the same relationship with her. Just mark off the days, one by one, until you're back on your feet. #3 hit me harder and faster, and I imagine #4 may do the same thing. Thanks for the tips (and warnings) about the search for a vein this time. I'll try eating sone salty stuff and I'll just grit my teeth and pull out the tissues in case they have to keep stabbing me. Yep, Josie, CKK and I have our final treatments this week. Josie and I are Tuesday, Ckk on Thursday. Let's add our "final infusion" photos to the FB page, as some others have done. It's raining here, so I won't get a walk today. I walked a bit yesterday and was shocked at how I was puffing and how my thigh muscles burned. I guess I'll just have to start slow and build up. Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 09:58PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Just hours to go before my final chemo!!! And Josie, too!! I've been up since 4:15. All sorts of feelings today...I'm nervous about their finding a good vein...I'm excited and relieved that this is the last time I'll have to do this...I'm dreading the last round of SE and wondering how bad the fatigue will be this time.. I had an embarrassing meltdown yesterday. All weekend, I had worked to wash, iron and hang a LOT of spring clothes to take to my favorite consignment shop. They were hanging on every door in the house. I knew yesterday was my only window for doing this for several weeks. I was at the shop and standing at the door, clothes hanging over my arm,  for its 10 AM opening. I could see employees in there. Finally, at 10:05, I rapped on the door. They ignored me. I knocked harder. A woman came to the door and not too nicely said they were closed for inventory.  I told her that yesterday was the only day I could drop off the clothes, that it would be probably 3 weeks before I could come back. She said, "Then come back in 3 weeks." I lost it then. I told her I was a breast cancer patient undergoing chemo, that my next treatment was today and I would not feel up to coming back, that I had worked all weekend to get these clothes ready. I started crying. She went to get the manager (a new one; I knew the old one), who came to the door. By then, I was almost sobbing. At first she was not so nice either, saying that they were jammed, their computer wasn't working and she could not make an exception. Then an employee who knew me and knew I had BC came up and hugged me, gave me a tissue and persuaded the manager to just take the clothes, that she would put them in the system later. I didn't realize how close to the surface my emotions were, how little frustrations and rejections could send me over the edge.   Rachel, so sorry about the thrush. Hope you can get something to take care of it today. And I meant to mention that my dreams also have been quite involved and dramatic, including a few nightmares. Heather and Gracie, hope that each day brings a little relief from the fatigue. I'll be right there with you, in bed, (oops, you know what I mean!!!) in a few days. Have a good day, everyone!

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2012 05:46PM WaveWhisperer wrote: I had my simulation today. It was a little tougher than I expected because I had to lie perfectly still, with my arms bent over my head, for about 35-40 minutes while the techs took lots of something (X-rays? photos?) and came in and out to gently readjust me several times. At least they put two warm blankets over me and for most of it my boobs weren't exposed. At one point I wished I had taken a Valium before going. Even though it was completely open, I had this tremendous urge to wave my arms and jump off the table. They also did more tattoos. I guess the last one were "trial" ones, and today's were a different color. My chest is painted from shoulder to belly button with magic marker lines, but they said those will wash off. Two good things, though. (Silver linings, as the nurse blogger would call them.) I found out I'll have to have only 22 treatments, 16 regular and 6 boosts, so I'll be through on April 17th!!! And I got the 8:30 a.m. time slot I wanted. Even though the center is just about 7 minutes away (poor Robin, I'm sorry you have to drive so long), I didn't want the rads to interrupt my day or come at the end of the day when I am already tired. They said the 8:30 slot is a coveted one, and it just opened up today when someone finished their treatments. Here's my chemo brain story of the day. When I got to the center, one of the nurses said, "You're getting a jump on things, aren't you? Or do you just want to make sure they don't run out of beer?" I had no idea what she was talking about, so I'm sure I looked puzzled. "Your green...," she said. I had dressed in green pants and a lighter green sweater this morning,  thinking that today was St. Patrick's Day!  OK, so happy St. Patrick's Day TOMORROW, ladies!!

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 08:55PM WaveWhisperer wrote: Melrose, so glad our postings have been of help. As you might have learned from reading our stories, much of the support we got was the result of our going through T/C together, at the same time. So, in addition to our topic, I heartily suggest that you read -- or FORM -- a topic for ladies starting T/C in April or May 2012. It also was helpful for us to add our diagnosis and chemo schedule to our signature, so we knew exactly who was getting chemo on certain days. Some of us were "chemo buddies," getting treatments on the same days. If you can't figure out how to do that, let us know. Chemo isn't for the faint of heart and spirit. Frankly, it's a tough road. It's tough on your body and your emotions. No one -- not even your closest family -- will truly understand your frustrations and the depths of your despair as you cope with myriad side effects. At times, you may wonder if you can even get through it. BUT, you WILL get through it. Your body and spirit both will recover. You WILL get your old life back. And, in the process, on these sites, you'll meet some wonderful women who will listen to you, talk to you, help you night or day. If you're lucky, like we have been, they will become the most special of friends, for life. FOR LIFE!!!!  Bless you, our new friend.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 04:40PM WaveWhisperer wrote: First, I want to thank all the wise, generous women on this site. Before learning about this site, I never had heard of the Oncotype test, my surgeon never mentioned it, and it was not included in any of the written material given me after my diagnosis. I had my first appointment with the medical oncologist today, and I asked about Oncotype. She seemed pleased that I was a knowledgeable patient and said it was something she definitely recommended in my case, since I already fell into somewhat of a gray area, with micrometastasis in one node, which some doctors consider node-positive and some consider node-negative. She said my PR+ER+HER2- would argue against chemo, but the grade 3 tumor and the micrometastasis might argue for it. She said the Oncotype results would help both of us decide the best treatment, although she did warn, as many of you did also, that the results still could be inconclusive. But I want as much information as possible and will feel better making a decision on further treatment (chemo or no chemo) after hearing from the Oncotype, the CT scan and the bone scan. Again, this is a marvelous resource!
